posts.name: Jacob Waiser
posts.cooked:
Hello,  
I have recently been elected as my team’s new mechanical lead and was hoping to find a comprehensive but small manufacturing challenge that will give my current members a refresher on all of our most used tools. My team often uses a miter saw, band saw, drill press/drill, lathe, taps, and obviously wrenches and screwdrivers. If anyone has any suggestions or anything your team does, it would be greatly appreciated!  

Thank you!

posts.name: Andrew
posts.cooked: We’re considering implementing an L1 only ground intake on an extra drive train we have, and if you have space available with your algae shooter, it could be an interesting mechanical challenge to take on.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5013 Pit Crew and Design (I do not speak for my team, just my opinions)

posts.name: Jacob Waiser
posts.cooked: Honestly, I like that idea, but with our current resources and future plans during the off-season, I’d prefer to focus on a couple of smaller projects that don’t involve our robot or building a new one. We might explore something similar later in the off-season, but likely won’t be ready yet. I’ll definitely keep that in mind, though. Thanks!

posts.name: Jacob Waiser
posts.cooked: To clarify, our offseason plan includes designing a robot for a past game, focusing on mechanisms we haven't built in a while, and then having someone with mechanical expertise construct some of these components for practice purposes.

This is what I would recommend doing. I assume you have made an elevator, possibly based on last year’s game. If not, consider creating a strong pivot mechanism to support it, possibly incorporating a pivoting arm as an extension of a subsystem you already understand. This design could be highly effective.

posts.name: Jacob Waiser
posts.cooked: We were working on a robot this year but ended up not including a telescoping arm on the back, so a cascading or chain elevator is something we plan to work on during the offseason. We’ve built telescoping arms for three consecutive years now. However, you mentioned the pivot mechanism, which has been challenging for us to make sturdy in the past. Any suggestions you have would be really helpful!

algae shooter, my beloved, that’s actually a fire robot.  
I think there are a lot of good pivoting elevators seen in 2023 as an incredibly powerful archetype (like 148, 6329, etc.), but honestly, if you’re already skilled with telescopes, you might not need it. Learning to make a chunky pivot and doing something like a 2910 arm could give you one of the most competitive archetypes recently. I might try creating a telescope with chain or string cascade rigging, similar to how 2910 and 359 do it, though using just string should still work fine. Do what feels comfortable for you; a telescope can serve nearly the same purpose as an elevator. If you want to learn how to build a sturdy pivot, I highly recommend checking out this page on FRCDesign: [2910 Dead Axle Pivot | FRCDesign.org](https://www.frcdesign.org/mechanism-examples/pivots/2910_2023_pivot/).

posts.name: Jacob Waiser
posts.cooked: We find stability issues with our telescoping arm, suggesting that a chain or string-based system might perform better. However, we would still prefer a larger chain-based elevator, especially considering potential future needs with larger recycling components.

posts.name: Jacob Waiser
posts.cooked: An example of the type of project I’m looking for is something from my rookie year where we were asked to create clamps from a C-channel and a bolt by cutting it down, drilling, and tapping a hole in the top. We then analyzed their precision and consistency. While it was a good exercise in basic tools, I’d like something a bit more complex with more steps involved.
